column14: Assibilation of *t' to *c' and of *d' to *dz'
column15: The change of *kt to *k't' before front vowels and *j
column17: The change of *kt to *t and of *k't' to *t'
column20: The change of *CelC to *CalC and of *CilC to *CulC
column22: The change of *t' to *č and of *d' to *dž
column28: The change of *i to *ь and of *u to *ъ
column30: Loss of post-consonantal *j and Kortlandt's compensatory lengthening
column32: The rise of secondary palatalization before front vowels
column33: Denasalization of *ę, *ę̄ to *a, *ā and of *ǫ, *ǭ to *ọ, *ọ̄
column35: The rise of a difference between strong and weak jers
column38: The loss of the acute tone
column41: The change of *īj to *ь2j and of *ūj to *ъ2j
column42: The loss of word-initial *j- before *ī and *ū
column43: The change of *ji, *jī to *i and of *wu, *wū to *u
column44: The shift of stress from post-hiatal *i, *ī and *u, *ū to an immediately preceding syllable
column48: The rise of secondary alatalization of *r in tautosyllabic position before *ь immediately followed by velars, labials, or palatalized dentals
column52: The change of palatal *l', *n' to palatalized *l', *n'
column53: The change of *ь to *e and of *ъ to *o
column54: The rise of stress in unaccentuated accentual units
column57: Regressive voice assimilation in consonant sequences and word-final devoicing
column58: Hardening of *š to *ṡ͘, and of *ž to *ż
column60: The change of *e to *o before hard consonants
column63: The change of *i, *ī to *y, *ȳ after hard consonants
column64: The change of *y, *ȳ to *i, *ī after velar consonants
column65: Secondary palatalization of *k, *g, *x by following front vowels
column67: The change of *ě to *i before palatalized dentals followed by a stressed front vowel or a
column69: Loss of non-palatalized *l in word-final position
column70: The change of *šč to *šš and of *ždž to *žž

column2: The velar obstruents *k, *g, *x changed to *tˊ, *dˊ, *ś if they were immediately preceded by *i, *ī, or *j, or by sequences consisting of *i and a nasal *n
column3: Back vowels were fronted after the palatal consonants *j, *tˊ,*dˊ, and *ś: *u > *i, *ū > *ī, *a > *e, *ā > *ē
column4: Tautosyllabic sequences of vowel and *w or *j were monophthongized: *aw, *āw, *ew, *ēw > *ọ̄; *aj, *āj > *ē; *ej, *ēj > *ẹ̄ > *ī
column5: *ē was backened to *ā after the palatal consonants *j, *č, *dž, *š, *tˊ, *dˊ, *ś
column7: *ẹ̄, which had been introduced as a result of the monophthongization of *ej, changed to *ī
column8: The velar obstruents *k, *g, *x changed to *tˊ, *dˊ, *ś if they were immediately by a front vowel resulting from monophthongization or by a sequence consisting of *w and a front vowel resulting from monophthongization
column9: A lateral *l was inserted between the labial consonants *p, *b, *m, *w and an immediately following *j
column10: Palatal *ś resulting from one of the two Common Slavic palatalizations (§§ 1, 7) change to palatalized *sʼ
column11: Acute word-initial sequences of *ar-, *al- followed by a consonant other than *j change to *rā˙-, *lā˙-, and non-acute to *ra-, *la-
column12: The accented shifted from a non-acute syllable onto the immediatly following syllable
column13: Acute tone was dropped on unaccented syllables
column14: *tˊ and dʼ resulting from one of two Common Slavic palatalizations (§§ 1, 7) assibilated to *cʼ and *dzʼ
column15: *kt change to kˊtˊ before immediately preceding front vowels (*e, *ē, *i, *ī) and *j
column16: The long vowels *ā, *ē were shortened before a tautosyllabic nasal *n: *ān, *ēn > *an, *en
column17: The sequences *kt and *k't' were simplified to *t and *t', respectively
column19: Sequences of a dental consonant and *j, cf. *tj, *dj, *sj, *zj, *rj, *lj, *nj, were "jotated" to *tˊj, *dˊj, *šj, *žj, *rʼj, *lˊj, *ńj; *s or *z immediately preceding a corresponding sequcne, was affected by the change as well: *stj, *zdj, *slj > *štˊj, *ždˊj, *šlˊj etc.
column20: Before a tautosyllabic lateral *l, the front vowels *e and *i changed to *a and *u, respectively
column21: The sequences *tl and *dl were simplified to *l
column22: *tˊ, *dˊ resulting from the change *kˊtˊ > tˊ (§ 16) and from Jotation (§ 18) developed further to *č and dž, respectively
column23: Tautosyllabic word-internal sequences *-al-, *-ar-, *-er-, *-el- changed to *-ala-, *-ara-, *-ere-, *-ele-; if the original seqence was accented, which was the case when it bore the acute tone or when it had received the accent as a result of Dybo's law (§ 11), the pleonastic sequence received an accent on the second syllable; NB: before *j, *-al-, *-ar-, *-er-, *-el- were heterosyllabic
column25: The word initial front vowels *e, *ē, *i, *ī, and *ā received a prothetic *j: *e-, *ē-, *i-, *ī-, *ā- > *je-, *jē-, *ji-, *jī-, *jā-
column26: Tautosyllabic sequences *en, *eń, *em, *in, *iń, *im changed to *ę̄ and tautosyllabic sequences *on, *oń, *om, *un, *uń, *um to *ǭ; NB: the corresponding sequences were heterosyllabic before *j and *lj
column27: PSl. *ē and *ē that resulted from monophthongization of aj, āj (§ 3) was raised to *ẹ̄, which is traditionally referred to as „Jat“ (ě), i.e., by the name that is used to write the corresponding sound in Old Church Slavonic
column28: Short *i and *u changed to *ь and *ъ, respectively; the pronunciation of the latter sounds was most probably located between that of *i and *u and of schwa.
column29: Word-final long vowels were shortened in polysyllabic words; an acute tone was erased in the course of this shortening
column30: Postconsonantal *j was lost; as a result of this loss, an immediately following vowel was lengthened
column31: Word-final consonant-sonorant-jer sequences were dissolved by inserting a jer between the consonant and the sonorang; the quality of the inserted jer depended on its environment: after velar consonants *ъ was inserted, after dental and labial consonants *ь, and if the sonorant was *w, the inserted vowel was *ъ
column32: Non-soft consonants became secondarily palatalized before front vowels
column34: Word-initial *jь- change to *i-; this includes sequences of *jь- that were introduced by j-prothesis (§ 24)
column35: Jers (*ъ, *ь) were strong when they occurred in tautosyllabic sequences before or after liquids (*r, *l), after nasals (*m, *n), and after *w, and in subsequent syllables containing jers in every even syllable counted from right to left; in other positions, jers counted as weak
column36: The accent shifted one syllable to the left from non-acute long vowels
column37: The accent shifted one syllable to the left from weak jers
column39: *ọ̄, *ọ resulting from monophthongization (§ 3) and denasalization (§ 33) change to *ū, *u
column40: *dž resulting from Jotation of *t and from the pre-Proto-Slavic First regressive Palatalization changed to *ž
column41: Long *ī and *ū followed by a glide *j changed to strong jers: *īj > *ь2j and *ūj > *ъ2j, respectively
column43: The glides *j and *w were lost before tautosyllabic high vowels: *ji, *jī > *i and *wu, *wū > *u, respectively
column44: The accent shifted by one syllable to the left from *i, *ī, *u, *ū that were preceded by a hiatus as a result of change of *ji, *jī to *i and of *wu, *wū to *u; in the course of this change *i, *ī and *u, *ū change to *j and *w, respectively
column46: Word-initial *je- change to *o- if it was immediately followed by a soft consonantsand if certain other conditions that have been proven difficult to determine were fulfilled
column47: *dz resulting from the Third and the Second palatalizations changed to palatalized *z'
column48: *r became palatalized in the position after *ь before a velar, labial, or palatalized dental consonant
column49: *ъ and *ь were lost in weak position
column50: As a result of the loss of weak years consonant clusters with a palatal as their final member arose; in these clusters, consonants assimilated to the palatal consonant
column51: Certain consonant clusters resulting from the loss of weak jers were simplified
column52: Palatal nasals and laterals (*l', *n') which had been introduced as a result of Jotation (§ 18) changed to their palatalized counterparts (*l', *n')
column53: *ъ and *ь which had been retained because they occurred in strong position (§ 34)
column54: Unaccented accentual units received a stress on their initial syllable
column57: In consonant clusters which had arisen as a result of the loss of weak jers, voiced consonants that took part in the voicing correlation assimilated to a following unvoiced consonant and vice versa; word-final voiced consonants were devoiced
column58: Soft *š and *ž changed to hard *ṡ͘ and *ż
column59: Palatalized *m' in word-final position was depalatalized to *m
column60: PSl. *e and *e resulting from the change *ь > *e (§ 52) change to *o if they were immediately followed by a hard consonant
column62: In consonant clusters which had arisen as a result of the loss of weak jers, most palatalized consonants assimilated to a following unpalatalized consonant and vice versa
column63: After hard consonants, high front vowels were backened: *i, *ī > *y, *ȳ
column64: After the velar consonants *k, *g, and *x, *y, *ȳ were fronted to *i, *ī
column65: The velar consonants *k, *g, and *x became palatalized before immediately following front vowels
column67: Jat (ě) changed to *i if it was followed by a sequence consisting of a paltalized dental consonant and a stressed front vowel or *a
column68: Apart from *u, unvoiced vowels were reduced; the quality of the resulting reduced vowel depended on the on its position in relation to the stressed syllable and on whether a preceding consonant was palatalized
column69: Postconsonental non-palatalized *l was lost in word-final position
column70: The second member of the sequences *šč and *ždž  were deaffricated: *šč > *šš, *ždž > *žž
